description:
This PR updates a bunch of things in the docs:

* It rewrites the objects section, which was previously objects and fields together.  This now separates them and goes through and lists all available objects, their usage, and links to their API docs.  
* Many of the object docstrings were inaccurate, so I updated them to match their actual usage.
* This adds a "box" function that hands on the dataset and creates a Region object without requiring a "center" value (it takes the midpoint between the left edge and right edge).  
* It adds a section to the Plotting docs primarily written by @jzuhone on the differences between the different projection "styles" (e.g. integrate, mip, sum, weighting and non-weighting).  I modified it so it would render correctly in latex mode.
* This updates the Derived Quantities section of the docs.
* Other small miscellaneous doc updates.
* Renamed the data_selection_and_fields cookbook to fields_and_unit_conversion so it was easier to find how to convert units for a field, one of the most important usages of units.
* Moved things around in the analyze table of contents
* consolidated the two surfaces descriptions into a single one.
* moved "creating_derived_fields" section to the dev docs with the other "creating" sections.
title: Docs Objects Update

content.raw: You need to do `ds.index` before this works.  Additionally, it has to be `ds.field_info['gas', 'pressure']`.
content.html: You need to do ds.index before this works. Additionally, it has to be ds.field_info['gas', 'pressure'].

content.html: Same here, needs to be the full field name tuple.

content.html: typo

content.html: Good call. I was just pulling this from the old docs, so I guess I didn't check to make sure this worked. I'll correct.

content.html: What? You don't like data dollections?!

content.raw: You sort of say this in words, but I think it would help to explicitly say that this is the same thing as `ds.region(ds.domain_center, ds.domain_left_edge, ds.domain_right_edge)`
content.html: You sort of say this in words, but I think it would help to explicitly say that this is the same thing as ds.region(ds.domain_center, ds.domain_left_edge, ds.domain_right_edge)

content.html: "by a point" maybe?

content.html: This section is really excellent.

content.raw: These are all classes, so I think you need to use the sphinx class role: `` :class:`~yt.path.to.ClassDefinition` ``.
content.html: These are all classes, so I think you need to use the sphinx class role: :class:`~yt.path.to.ClassDefinition`.

content.raw: oh, you're right!
content.html: oh, you're right!

content.raw: This doesn't work anymore.  You need to define a new subclass of `DerivedQuantity` to create a new one.  That said, I don't think anyone has actually done that in a user script.  I think we agreed to remove this section during one of the last doc hangouts.
content.html: This doesn't work anymore. You need to define a new subclass of DerivedQuantity to create a new one. That said, I don't think anyone has actually done that in a user script. I think we agreed to remove this section during one of the last doc hangouts.

content.raw: Good catch.
content.html: Good catch.

content.html: These are called YTSelectionContainer2D now.

content.raw: Oh, I can do that.  So we won't allow any custom derived quantities from now on?  That's fine, just checking.
content.html: Oh, I can do that. So we won't allow any custom derived quantities from now on? That's fine, just checking.

content.raw: Maybe eventually.  It definitely needs work and I wouldn't feel comfortable leaving it in the docs for Wednesday.  I'm also not convinced that the ability to define custom derived quantities was used terribly often.
content.html: Maybe eventually. It definitely needs work and I wouldn't feel comfortable leaving it in the docs for Wednesday. I'm also not convinced that the ability to define custom derived quantities was used terribly often.

content.html: OK, I'll remove it for now.

content.raw: These can work on particle fields, too.  They just can't work across field types -- if the filter is based on particle values, it can't filter mesh values.
content.html: These can work on particle fields, too. They just can't work across field types -- if the filter is based on particle values, it can't filter mesh values.
